pre_attack: What constitutes criminal trespass in Singapore?

Whoever enters into or upon property in the possession of another with intent to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult or annoy any person in possession of such property, or having lawfully entered into or upon such property, unlawfully remains there with intent thereby to intimidate, insult or annoy any such person, or with intent to commit an offence, is said to commit “criminal trespass"

Explanation.—The introduction of any part of the criminal trespasser's body is entering sufficient to constitute house-breaking.[15/2019]443. [Repealed by Act 15 of 2019]444. [Repealed by Act 15 of 2019]445. [Repealed by Act 15 of 2019]446. [Repealed by Act 15 of 2019]Punishment for criminal trespass447. Whoever commits criminal trespass shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 months, or with fine which may extend to $1,500, or with both.

(5) A person may be a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence in Singapore even though all or any of the acts constituting the criminal conspiracy were done outside Singapore.Explanation.—-It is immaterial whether the offence is the ultimate object of such agreement, or is merely incidental to that object.Informal Consolidation - version in force from 31/1/2024

(2) A person may be a party to a criminal conspiracy despite the existence of facts of which he is unaware which make the commission of the offence impossible.[15/2019](3) A person may be a party to a criminal conspiracy even though any other person who agrees to commit the offence that is the subject of the conspiracy or to cause that offence to be committed does not intend to carry out that agreement.[15/2019](4) A person may be a party to a criminal conspiracy in Singapore to commit an offence outside Singapore, which would constitute an offence if committed in Singapore.[15/2019]

'explosive substance" shall be deemed to include any materialsfor making any explosive substance and any bomb, grenade,apparatus, machine, implement or material used or intended to be used or adapted for causing or aiding in causing any explosion in or with any explosive substance and any part ofsuch bomb, grenade, apparatus, machine or implement;"police officer’ includes any member of the Special Constabulary constituted under Part 8 of the Police ForceAct 2004;"subversive document" means any document which contains --(a) any subversive matter;(b) any propaganda or matter supporting, propagating or advocating acts prejudicial to the public safety in Singapore or the maintenance of public order therein or  inciting  to  violence  therein or  counselling disobedience to the law thereof or to any lawful order therein; or

"Criminal Procedure Rules" (a) means the Criminal Procedure Rules 2018 made under this Code and any other written law by the Criminal Procedure Rules Committee  constituted under section 428A; and(b) includes any subsidiary legislation deemed undersection 428A(15) to be Criminal Procedure Rules;"criminal record" means the record of any ——(a)  conviction in any court, or subordinate military court established under section 80 of the Singapore ArmedForces Act 1972;(b) order made under section 34(2) of the Misuse ofDrugs Act 1973;(c) supervision order made under section 16 of theIntoxicating Substances Act 1987;

To answer this question, I will refer to the relevant fragments from Document: Penal Code 1871.pdf:

4. Criminal trespass ##4$$
Criminal trespass
441. Whoever enters into or upon property in the possession of another with intent to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult or annoy any person in possession of such property, or having lawfully entered into or upon such property, unlawfully remains there with intent thereby to intimidate, insult or annoy any such person, or with intent to commit an offence, is said to commit “criminal trespass'.

442. Whoever commits criminal trespass by entering into, or remaining in, any building, tent, container or vessel used as a human dwelling, or any building used as a place for worship or as aplace for the custody of property, is said to commit "house-breaking"

Therefore, according to the Penal Code 1871.pdf document:

Criminal trespass in Singapore is constituted by: ##0$$
- Entering into or upon property in possession of another with intent to commit an offence or intimidate/insult/annoy any person.
- Unlawfully remaining on lawfully entered property with intent to intimidate/insult/annoy.

House-breaking, a specific type of criminal trespass, involves entering into or remaining in buildings used as human dwellings, places for worship, or custody of property.

The answer you are looking for can be found in the Penal Code of Singapore. According to this code, criminal trespass is constituted by entering any part of one's body into a property without permission from the owner or occupier.

In summary, according to the Penal Code 1871.pdf document:

* The introduction of any part of the criminal trespasser's body is sufficient to constitute house-breaking.
* Whoever commits criminal trespass shall be punished with imprisonment for up to 3 months, or with fine which may extend to $1,500, or with both.
